It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. Water the plant deeply once or twice a week, depending on the local climate and soil type. During hotter periods, the frequency of watering may need to increase. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Ensure that the soil drains well and that excess water can escape to prevent waterlogging. In winter, when the plant's growth rate is slower, reduce watering frequency to prevent stress due to excessive moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coccinia grandis thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least five to six hours of direct sunlight each day for optimal growth and fruit production. If planted in a location with too much shade, the plant's growth may become leggy, and fruiting can be significantly reduced. In very hot climates, providing the plant with some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. Make sure to plant Coccinia grandis in a sunny spot where it can climb or spread to maximize exposure to sunlight for the healthiest growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coccinia grandis helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. Regularly remove any dead, damaged, or diseased vines to prevent the spread of disease. You can also trim back any overly long or unruly shoots to maintain the desired size and promote bushier growth. Pruning is generally best done during the growing season, in early spring or after the plant has finished fruiting. Use clean, sharp tools to make cuts just above a leaf node to encourage new growth. Pruning not only helps control the plant's size but also improves air circulation and sunlight penetration."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Ivy gourd","description":"Coccinia grandis, the ivy gourd, also known as scarlet gourd and Kowai, is a tropical vine. It is also very popular in the Indian state of West Bengal, known Kunduri in Bengali with popular Bengali cuisine like Kunduri Posto. In the indian north eastern state of Assam it is called as Kunduli and Tondekayi (ತೊಂಡೆಕಾಯಿ ) in Kannada. In Southeast Asia, it is grown for its edible young shoots and edible fruits.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia","Indian Subcontinent"],"other_name":["Ivy gourd"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mildew"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Coccinia grandis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17808,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Thevetia ahouai should be watered moderately, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it is important to ensure good drainage by using well-draining soil. During the warmer months, more frequent watering may be needed, but in the cooler months, water less frequently. Always check the top inch of the soil; if it's dry, it's a good indication that the plant needs water. Letting the plant dry out slightly between watering promotes strong root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Thevetia ahouai thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily, which promotes healthy growth and abundant flowering. In areas with very hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorching. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window. Adequate sunlight is crucial for this plant to produce its vibrant flowers, so ensure it's positioned in an area where it receives plenty of light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Thevetia ahouai to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. The best time to prune is in early spring, before the new growth starts. Use clean, sharp shears to make clean cuts just above a node or a bud. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossed branches to improve air circulation and light penetration. You may also trim lightly throughout the growing season to remove spent flowers and encourage additional blooming. Avoid heavy pruning late in the season to prevent damage during colder months."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":null,"description":"html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota tr{background:transparent!important}html.skin-theme-clientpref-night .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota img{background:white}@media(prefers-color-scheme:dark){html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota tr{background:transparent!important}html.skin-theme-clientpref-os .mw-parser-output .infobox.biota img{background:white}}","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Thevetia ahouai"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to prevent root rot. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant moderately—every two to four weeks, depending on the climate and pot size. In the winter months, reduce watering significantly, ensuring the soil remains dry. Always water from the base and ensure proper drainage to avoid waterlogging, as the plant is susceptible to root rot if overwatered."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coryphantha octacantha prefers full sun to partial shade. Ideally, this cactus should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to mimic its native arid environment, which is essential for its health and flowering. If growing indoors, place the cactus near a south or west-facing window where it can get ample sunlight. However, in extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade can prevent sunburn. Ensure gradual acclimatization to direct sunlight when moving the plant outdoors from an indoor setting to prevent shock."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Coryphantha octacantha is generally not necessary as this cactus grows slowly and maintains a neat appearance naturally. However, if any damaged or diseased parts appear, they should be carefully removed using clean, sharp tools to minimize damage and reduce the risk of infection. Dead flowers can be removed to prevent rotting. Use tongs to handle the plant, if needed, to avoid injury from its spines. Regular inspection can ensure the plant remains healthy, but minimal pruning is typically required."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States","Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Coryphantha octacantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is an unusual bellflower in that its flowers are usually flat and not bell-shaped. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17709,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mammillaria elongata, commonly known as the \"ladyfinger cactus,\" prefers infrequent but thorough watering. Allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings, typically every 1-2 weeks during the growing season (spring and summer). Reduce watering significantly in the fall and winter when the cactus is dormant, possibly watering only once a month or less. It's crucial to avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot; ensure excess water drains away fully. Use a well-draining cactus or succulent mix to facilitate proper drainage and mimic their natural environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria elongata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can also handle direct sunlight for a few hours each day, but prolonged exposure to harsh midday sun, especially in hotter regions, should be avoided to prevent sunburn. A south or west-facing windowsill is ideal. If grown indoors, supplementing with a grow light can help during the darker winter months. Ensure the plant receives at least 4-6 hours of bright light daily for optimal growth, rotating the pot occasionally to ensure even exposure and prevent lopsided growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria elongata is generally not necessary unless you wish to remove dead or damaged segments. Use sterile scissors or pruners to carefully snip away any unhealthy parts at the base of the stem. If the cactus becomes too crowded, gently remove offsets or \"pups\" that form around the base to propagate new plants or to maintain plant health. Always handle the cactus with care to avoid injury from its spines. It's best to handle pruning tasks during the spring when the plant is actively growing, allowing it to recover more quickly."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Gold Lace Cactus","description":"Mammillaria elongata (gold lace cactus, ladyfinger cactus) is a species of flowering plant in the Cactaceae family, native to central Mexico. Growing to 15 cm (6 in) tall by 30 cm (12 in) wide, it consists of densely packed clusters of elongated oval stems, covered in harmless yellow or brown spines, and in spring producing white or yellow flowers. It is among the commonest and most variable of its genus in nature, and is a popular subject for cultivation. It...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Gold Lace Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Mealybugs"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria elongata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16319,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dryas integrifolia is adapted to cold, arid environments where it's native, and therefore requires minimal watering when cultivated in gardens. Water the plant sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out between sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot, especially if drainage is poor. Generally, watering once every couple of weeks during dry periods is sufficient, but reduce frequency drastically during its dormant period in the winter. Ensure the soil drains well to prevent water from accumulating around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dryas integrifolia thrives in full sunlight and requires at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight a day. This plant is well-suited to alpine and tundra-like conditions, making it ideal for rock gardens or exposed, sunny beds where it can mimic its natural environment. It can tolerate partial shade but in such conditions, it may become less vigorous in flower production. Ensure your planting location is bright to encourage robust growth and flowering. Shade can make it leggy and reduce its overall health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dryas integrifolia is not necessary for its health, but light trimming can help maintain its shape and encourage denser growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves, which helps prevent disease and improves aesthetics. Perform pruning after flowering if desired, but take care not to cut into thick, woody stems, as this can damage the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as it naturally grows well without much intervention. Focus on removing only the unhealthy or overly long parts."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Entireleaf Mountain-Avens","description":"Dryas integrifolia is a species of flowering plant in the rose family known by the common names entireleaf mountain-avens, white mountain-avens, northern white mountain avens, and mountain avens. It is native to northern parts of North America, where it occurs from Alaska across Canada to Greenland. It is a common species of the Arctic and it is probably the most common flowering plant on some of the western Arctic islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Arctic regions"],"other_name":["Entireleaf Mountain-Avens"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Dryas integrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17513,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amanita caesarea, known as Caesar's mushroom, thrives best in humid environments typical of its natural Mediterranean habitat. When cultivating or maintaining this mushroom, true watering isn't applicable as it is with plants; rather, ensuring that the environment simulates natural humidity levels is important. If grown outdoors, natural rainfall often suffices, but in drier climates, maintaining higher humidity through misting can be beneficial. Over-watering, or waterlogging the site, can be detrimental, as it needs well-drained conditions. Hence, providing consistent moisture, not saturation, best replicates its favored conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amanita caesarea prefers environments that mimic the dappled sunlight commonly found in woodlands. Being a mushroom, it does not require direct sunlight—in fact, direct exposure could be detrimental. Instead, it thrives best in partially shaded areas where indirect sunlight can filter through. If cultivating these mushrooms, positioning around deciduous trees where they receive filtered light works well. The key is to balance enough light to encourage growth while avoiding conditions that can dry the mushrooms or the soil excessively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Unlike traditional plants, Amanita caesarea does not require pruning in the typical sense, as it is a mushroom. However, if you are cultivating it, regularly checking for and removing decayed or older mushrooms can help maintain a healthy environment for the developing fungi. This ensures that nutrients are not drained by decomposing material and can instead nourish younger, healthy growth. Removing debris or organic matter at the mushroom's base also helps prevent the spread of mold or pests that can affect their growth."}],"care_level":"Extreme","common_name":"Caesar's mushroom","description":"Amanita caesarea, commonly known as Caesar's mushroom, is a highly regarded edible mushroom in the genus Amanita, native to southern Europe and North Africa. While it was first described by Giovanni Antonio Scopoli in 1772, this mushroom was a known favorite of early rulers of the Roman Empire.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"High","origin":["Southern Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Caesar's mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal infections"],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Amanita caesarea"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid heavy pruning during its flowering period, as this can reduce its blooming."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Hyptis","description":"Hyptis suaveolens, pignut or chan, is a branching pseudocereal plant native to tropical regions of Mexico, Central, the West Indies, and South America, as well as being naturalized in tropical parts of Africa, Asia and Australia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17415,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Usnea intermedia, being a lichen, does not require traditional watering like typical plants. It absorbs moisture directly from the air, which allows it to thrive in humid environments. To ensure its health, maintain a high humidity level around the lichen. Avoid watering directly, as excessive water can lead to decay or diminish its ability to absorb nutrients. If growing indoors, misting occasionally can help maintain suitable moisture levels, but it's crucial to ensure ample airflow to prevent stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Usnea intermedia prefers partial shade to indirect sunlight, as direct exposure to harsh sunlight can cause it to dry out and suffer damage. Ideally, place it in an area where it can receive filtered light for a few hours each day. In natural settings, Usnea grows well on tree branches where it gets dappled sunlight, and this can be mimicked in cultivation conditions. Ensure it is not in complete darkness as some light is necessary for its photosynthetic partners (algae) to produce nutrients."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not typically necessary for Usnea intermedia, as lichens grow at a very slow pace and do not require shaping. However, you can gently trim any dead or damaged parts that may occur over time. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make precise cuts. Care should be taken not to disturb the remaining healthy lichen, as excessive pruning can harm its delicate structure. Regularly check for any potential decay or pest damage and address it promptly to keep your lichen healthy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Arizona Beard Lichen","description":"Usnea intermedia (western bushy beard) is a grayish-yellowish pale green, irregularly much-branching, stiff shrubby foliose lichen commonly anchored on holdfasts on trees, often on oaks.:201 Abundant apothecia are convex discs with a ring or thallus-like margin having tendril-like fringe radiating from it.:201 It was formerly called U. arizonica in North America.:201","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Arizona Beard Lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Usnea intermedia"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is adaptable to various light conditions, but ensuring adequate sunlight will help the tree develop a strong, dense canopy, essential for its health and vitality."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Quercus glauca should be done primarily in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. The goal is to maintain the desired shape and remove any dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote good air circulation within the canopy. Always use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts and reduce damage to the bark."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"ring-cupped oak","description":"Quercus glauca (syn. Cut back the flower stalks to the base after flowering to tidy up the plant and prevent seed dispersal. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to avoid any damage or disease transmission during pruning."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"northern evening-primrose","description":"Oenothera parviflora, the northern evening primrose, is a species of flowering plant in the family Onagraceae. At the end of the growing season, usually in late fall, cut back the entire plant to a few inches above the ground. This helps remove dead or diseased foliage and allows the plant to rejuvenate. Avoid heavy pruning during the winter as it can harm the plant. During hot, dry periods, you may need to water it more often, whereas in cooler weather or when growing in the ground, the plant will require less frequent watering. Containers dry out more quickly, so monitor potted plants closely. Overhead watering should be avoided to prevent foliage diseases, use a soaker hose or water at the base."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Iberis sempervirens thrives in full sun to partial shade. For optimal flowering and growth, aim to provide the plant with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In regions with very hot summers, partial afternoon shade can help prevent the plant's foliage from scorching and keep it looking its best. While it can tolerate some shade, too little light may result in reduced flowering and a leggier plant. It performs well in well-drained soils and rock gardens where sunlight is ample, ensuring robust growth and a profusion of delicate white flowers in the spring."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Iberis sempervirens helps maintain its neat appearance and encourages a compact growth habit. After the plant has finished blooming in late spring or early summer, shear back the stems by about one-third. This helps promote bushiness and can encourage a potential second bloom. Remove any dead or damaged stems throughout the year to keep the plant healthy. Regular deadheading of spent flowers during the blooming season can also help extend the flowering period and prevent the plant from becoming too leggy. As an ornamental plant it is a spring-blooming favourite, often seen cascading over rocks and walls, or used as groundcover. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16819,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Phyllodoce caerulea, commonly known as purple mountain heather, requires careful watering to thrive. However, ensure that the soil has good drainage to prevent root rot. During winter, reduce watering significantly as the plant’s water needs decrease. It is also beneficial to water in the morning, allowing the foliage to dry out during the day, reducing the risk of fungal diseases."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phyllodoce caerulea prefers a position in part shade to full sun. In cooler climates, it can tolerate more sun exposure, but in warmer areas, providing some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Ideally, morning sun with afternoon shade works best. This plant thrives in conditions that mimic its native alpine environments, where it receives direct sun but also experiences cooler, damp conditions at times. Ensuring proper light exposure will help the plant bloom profusely and maintain vibrant foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Phyllodoce caerulea is an essential part of its care, primarily to maintain its shape and encourage healthy growth. It is best to prune the plant in early spring before the new growth starts. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to allow sunlight and air to penetrate the inner parts of the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as it can negatively impact blooming. Lightly trimming the tips can promote bushier growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning tools to make precise cuts and minimize stress on the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Blue Mountain-heath","description":"Phyllodoce caerulea, known as blue heath in British English and purple mountain heather or blue mountainheath in American English, is an evergreen species of dwarf shrub that grows up to around 15 cm (6 in) tall, and bears clusters of 2–6 purple flowers. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17711,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mammillaria compressa, a type of cactus, requires minimal watering. During its growing season in spring and summer, water it deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. Typically, watering once every two to four weeks is sufficient, depending on the humidity and temperature of your environment. In the fall and winter, reduce watering significantly and water only sparingly—about once a month or less—since this is its dormant period. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has adequate drainage and only water when the soil is very dry."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria compressa thrives in bright, indirect sunlight for most of the day. Ideally, provide at least six hours of bright light daily to help it maintain its healthy growth and compact shape. If grown indoors, a south or west-facing window is ideal. However, protect it from direct, intense sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, to prevent sunburn. Outdoors, it can also be placed in a location that gets some shade during peak afternoon hours. Adjust the plant's location according to the level of sunlight and ensure it doesn’t get too much shade, which can hinder its growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Mammillaria compressa is relatively simple and mainly involves removing dead or damaged parts to maintain a tidy appearance. It's important to use sterilized tools to prevent disease, and prune during the active growing season, which is in the spring or early summer. Remove any spent blooms or brown sections by cutting them off at the base. If offsets form at the base of the plant, they can be removed if space is desired or left to grow for a fuller appearance. Always handle with care due to the spines, and wear gloves if necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mother of Hundreds","description":"Mammillaria compressa is a species of cactus in the subfamily Cactoideae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":["Mother of Hundreds"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria compressa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It can tolerate some degree of shade, but flowering and growth might be less vigorous. Ideally, it should receive 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooming. Ensuring it has enough light will result in more abundant flowers and denser foliage, enhancing its ornamental value."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Sorbaria sorbifolia in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. This plant benefits from regular pruning to maintain shape, encourage bushier growth, and remove dead or damaged branches. Cut back old stems at the base to allow new shoots to develop, and thin out overcrowded branches to improve air circulation. After flowering, spent flower clusters can also be trimmed to maintain a tidy appearance. The plant is quite hardy, so it can tolerate heavy pruning if needed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sorbaria","description":"Sorbaria sorbifolia is commonly known as false spiraea, also spelled false spirea. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17315,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Dimocarpus longan, commonly known as Longan, requires consistent watering to thrive. During the growing season, it should be watered deeply once or twice a week to keep the soil evenly moist but not waterlogged. It is essential to allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. In the dormant period, reduce watering frequency, ensuring the soil remains slightly moist. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and regulate temperature. Monitoring the plant for signs of overwatering, such as yellowing leaves, is crucial to maintaining its health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Dimocarpus longan thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun each day for optimal growth and fruit production. It is best planted in a location where it can receive maximum sunlight exposure, as inadequate light may lead to poor growth and reduced fruit yield. In particularly hot climates, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. If growing indoors or in a greenhouse, ensure the plant is placed near a south-facing window or use grow lights to supplement natural light if necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is essential for Dimocarpus longan to promote healthy growth and a desirable shape. Pruning should be done annually, ideally after the fruit harvest or during the late winter to early spring while the plant is still dormant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve airflow and light penetration. Cutting back long branches can also help manage the size of the tree and encourage new growth and fruit production. Ensure using clean, sharp tools to prevent the spread of disease and make clean cuts just above a node or lateral branch."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Longan","description":"Dimocarpus longan, commonly known as the longan (/ˈlɒŋɡən/), is a tropical tree species that produces edible fruit. It is one of the better-known tropical members of the soapberry family (Sapindaceae), to which the lychee, rambutan, guarana, korlan, pitomba, guinep and ackee also belong. The fruit of the longan are similar to that of the lychee, but less aromatic in taste. It is native to tropical Asia and China.","family":null,"flower_color":"Cream","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","India"],"other_name":["Longan"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fruit borer","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Grafting Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Dimocarpus longan"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17515,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Phoenix roebelenii, commonly known as the Pygmy Date Palm, prefers moderate watering. Allow the top 1-2 inches of soil to dry out between waterings. It is important not to let the plant completely dry out or remain waterlogged. In its growing season, spring through summer, it may require more frequent watering, while in winter, water less often. The key is to maintain consistently moist, but not soggy, soil. Using well-draining soil and ensuring that the pot has good drainage will help prevent overwatering issues such as root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phoenix roebelenii thrives well with indirect or filtered sunlight. It prefers bright, indirect light but can also adapt to partial shade. If keeping outdoors, place it in a location with some protection from the harsh afternoon sun to prevent leaf scorching. If indoors, an east or west-facing window is ideal, or provide supplementary light if necessary. Too much direct sunlight without acclimation can lead to burned leaves, while too little light may slow its growth. Proper light conditions are essential for its healthy, lush foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning your Phoenix roebelenii should focus on removing dead, damaged, or yellowing fronds to encourage healthy growth. This is usually done in the spring or early summer. Use sterilized, sharp pruning shears to avoid introducing diseases. Cut the fronds close to the trunk but be careful not to cut too close as to damage the trunk itself. Avoid removing green fronds as these are crucial for the plant’s photosynthesis. It's also important not to over-prune as this can stress the plant and affect its growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pygmy Date Palm","description":"Phoenix roebelenii, with common names of pygmy date palm, miniature date palm or just robellini, is a species of date palm native to southeastern Asia, from southwestern China (Yunnan Province), northern Laos and northern Vietnam, (in Dien Bien Province, Ha Giang Province, Cao Bang Province, Lang Son Province). The name is sometimes mistakenly cited as roebelinii.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Southeast Asia"],"other_name":["Pygmy Date Palm"],"pest_susceptibility":["Spider Mites","Scale Insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Phoenix roebelenii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid direct sunlight, as it may damage the plant. If growing outside, ensure it is shaded by larger plants or structures to mimic its natural, forest-floor environment."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Dryopteris wallichiana is relatively minimal. Remove dead or damaged fronds as needed to maintain the plant's appearance and to prevent the spread of any diseases. In early spring, cut back old, tatty fronds to make space for fresh new growth. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant or spreading infections."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Wallich's wood fern","description":"Dryopteris wallichiana, the alpine wood fern, is a robust species of deciduous or semi-evergreen fern in the family Dryopteridaceae, native to the Himalayas, Hawaii, Mexico and Jamaica. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16131,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Caragana arborescens, commonly known as Siberian Pea Shrub, requires moderate watering. It is quite drought-tolerant once established, which means it prefers well-drained soil and can survive with minimal watering. During its first year, however, it should be watered regularly to help establish a strong root system. Avoid over-watering, as the plant does not tolerate waterlogged soils well. In dry or hot climates, ensure the shrub receives water during extended dry periods. For optimal growth, provide water deep into the soil, encouraging deep root growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Caragana arborescens thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal growth and flowering are best achieved when the shrub receives ample sunlight. If planted in areas with too much shade, the plant may become leggy, with fewer flowers and slower growth. It's a resilient species that can adapt to a variety of environments, but for lush foliage and prolific flowering, a sunny spot in your garden or landscape is ideal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Caragana arborescens should occur annually, ideally in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape, encourages flowering, and removes any dead or crossing branches. Start by cutting back any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Then thin out overcrowded areas to improve air circulation within the shrub. While the plant can tolerate substantial pruning, trimming too much may reduce flowering, so aim for a balanced approach. Proper pruning will not only help retain its form but also invigorate the shrub for vibrant growth each season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Siberian peashrub","description":"Caragana arborescens, the Siberian peashrub, Siberian pea-tree, or caragana, is a species of legume native to Siberia and parts of China (Heilongjiang Xinjiang) and neighboring Mongolia and Kazakhstan. It was taken to the United States by Eurasian immigrants, who used it as a food source while travelling west. In some areas of the United States it is considered an invasive species.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Siberia","Mongolia"],"other_name":["Siberian peashrub"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Caragana arborescens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16720,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Oenothera tetraptera, commonly known as evening primrose, prefers well-draining soil and requires moderate watering. During the winter months, watering should be reduced. It is best to allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent excess moisture accumulation. In general, adjusting the watering frequency based on the rainfall and climate conditions in your area is advisable for optimal plant health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Oenothera tetraptera thrives in full sun, meaning it requires at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. However, in very hot regions, some afternoon shade might be beneficial to protect the plant from intense midday sun. Finding the right balance of sunlight exposure is key; too little sun can result in poor flowering and leggy growth, while too much can lead to heat stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Oenothera tetraptera involves removing spent flowers and dead or diseased stems to encourage new growth and maintain a tidy appearance. It is best to prune after the plant has finished its main flowering period. This trimming helps to extend the blooming season by preventing seed formation and redirecting the plant's energy towards producing more buds. Cut back the stems to the base if they start to look untidy, especially in late winter or early spring before new growth appears. Regular pruning will promote a bushier form and enhance the overall health and vigor of the plant."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fourwing Evening Primrose","description":"Oenothera tetraptera, known as fourwing evening primrose, is a species of flowering plant in the evening primrose family (Onagraceae) native to the Americas. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16919,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ribes alpinum, also known as the alpine currant, prefers consistently moist soil but can tolerate short periods of drought once established. During its growing season (spring through summer), water it thoroughly once a week, ensuring the soil remains evenly moist. Reduce watering in the fall as the plant prepares for dormancy, requiring less moisture. Ensure good drainage, as standing water can harm the roots, possibly leading to root rot, particularly in poorly draining soils or areas of excessive rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ribes alpinum thrives in full sun to partial shade. It performs best with at least four to six hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to less vigorous growth and fewer blooms. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can protect the plant from excessive heat. Additionally, planting it in locations with adequate light will ensure good air circulation, reducing the risk of fungal diseases. Plan your planting location according to its light needs for optimal growth and health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Ribes alpinum in late winter or early spring before new growth starts, or in late summer after the plant has flowered. Regular pruning helps maintain a compact shape and encourages healthy growth. Remove dead or damaged branches to keep the shrub vigorous and healthy. For a more formal appearance, prune back the outermost growths lightly to shape the plant. It's essential not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant. Thin out older stems at the base to promote air circulation and reduce disease risk."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Currant","description":"Ribes alpinum, known as mountain currant or alpine currant, is a small deciduous shrub native to central and northern Europe from Finland and Norway south to the Alps and Pyrenees; in the south of its range, it is confined to high altitudes. It is scarce in western Europe, in Britain being confined to a small number of sites in northern England and Wales.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Mountain Currant"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ribes alpinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

The Appalachian plants are classified as Magnolia fraseri var. fraseri, and the more coastal plants as M. fraseri var. pyramidata. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17417,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Helianthemum apenninum, commonly known as the white rockrose, prefers well-drained soil and is somewhat drought-tolerant. Water the plant moderately during its growing season in spring and summer, ensuring the soil dries out between watering sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot, especially if the soil does not drain well. Cut back on watering during the fall and winter months when the plant is not actively growing. Rainwater or distilled water is preferable to avoid the buildup of salts in the soil, especially if your tap water is hard."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Helianthemum apenninum thrives in full sunlight and needs at least six hours of direct sun each day to grow and bloom effectively. An ideal location would be south-facing in the Northern Hemisphere, ensuring it receives the maximum amount of sunlight. While it can tolerate partial shade, reduced sunlight may lead to fewer blooms and a less robust overall appearance. Ensure the planting area is not overshadowed by taller plants or structures so the rockrose can receive ample light throughout its optimal growth periods."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Helianthemum apenninum is usually performed in late spring or early summer right after it finishes flowering. To maintain a neat appearance and encourage bushier growth, trim back about one-third of the plant. Remove any dead, damaged, or crossing branches to improve air circulation and overall health. Avoid heavy pruning, especially into the old wood, as it can affect the plant's ability to recover and flower in the following season. Lightly trimming spent flowers can also prolong the blooming period."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"White Rock-rose","description":"Helianthemum apenninum, the white rock-rose, is a white-flowering rock rose found in dry grassy and rocky places across large parts of Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["White Rock-rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Helianthemum apenninum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17019,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Spermacoce verticillata, commonly known as shrubby false buttonweed, prefers moderate watering. It's essential to keep the soil consistently moist, but not overly saturated, to avoid root rot. During the growing season, ensure that the plant receives water regularly, typically once a week or more often if the climate is particularly dry or hot. Reduce the frequency of watering in the dormant season but do not allow the soil to completely dry out. Ensure that the container or planting area has adequate drainage to prevent standing water, which can harm the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Spermacoce verticillata thrives in full sunlight conditions and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish. It can tolerate some partial shade, especially in hotter climates, but too much shade may result in reduced flowering and leggy growth. When planting, ensure that it is positioned in a location that receives ample direct sunlight throughout the day. If growing indoors, place near a south-facing window or use grow lights to replicate its sunlight needs. Proper sunlight exposure will ensure vigorous growth and blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Spermacoce verticillata involves shaping the plant to maintain its form and removing any damaged or dead stems. Pruning should be done in the growing season, typically spring or early summer, using clean and sharp tools to avoid plant damage or disease. Cut back any overgrown sections to encourage denser growth and to prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Remove any flowers that have wilted or died to promote more blooms. Regular trimming will keep the plant healthy and looking its best while providing a fuller appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"shrubby false buttonweed","description":"Spermacoce verticillata, the shrubby false buttonweed, is a species of plant that belongs to the family Rubiaceae...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America","Caribbean"],"other_name":["shrubby false buttonweed"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Spermacoce verticillata"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16421,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galium lanceolatum prefers consistently moist soil but shouldn't be waterlogged. Water the plant regularly to keep the soil evenly damp, especially during its growth period, but allow the top inch of the soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. During dormancy in cooler months, reduce watering frequency and maintain a slightly drier soil. Monitoring the soil moisture level is critical to ensure the plant's health, as both under-watering and over-watering can be detrimental. Use rainwater or distilled water if possible to avoid any long-term salt buildup from tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium lanceolatum thrives in partial shade to full shade conditions. It can handle brief periods of dappled sunlight, especially in the cooler parts of the day like early morning or late afternoon. Direct, intense sun is generally not recommended, as it can cause leaf scorching and stress the plant. Its natural habitat often involves sheltered areas, so replicating this environment will help the plant flourish. Placing it under trees or shaded by larger plants would be ideal to mimic its preferred conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium lanceolatum is generally minimal but beneficial for maintaining its appearance and health. Trim back any dead or damaged stems regularly to promote fresh growth. Removing spent flowers can also encourage a longer blooming season. In early spring, before new growth begins, you can perform a light shaping prune if necessary to maintain a neat form. Be mindful to avoid over-pruning as this can lead to a reduction in flowering. Sterilize pruning tools before use to prevent the spread of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Torrey's Wild Licorice","description":"Galium lanceolatum (lanceleaf wild licorice) is a species of plants in the Rubiaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Torrey's Wild Licorice"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Galium lanceolatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This tree can produce a sap that can be irritating to the skin and eyes, so it's essential to wear gloves and goggles while handling it. Regular pruning also helps in maintaining a manageable size, especially if grown in a garden setting, to prevent it from becoming too large or invasive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"milky mangrove","description":"Excoecaria agallocha, a mangrove species, belongs to the genus Excoecaria of the family Euphorbiaceae. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16225,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Colubrina greggii is a hardy shrub that is drought-tolerant, requiring minimal watering once established. It is best to water deeply but infrequently. Ensure the soil dries out between watering to prevent root rot, which occurs due to overwatering. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, water every two to three weeks if there’s no rainfall. In the cooler months, decrease watering frequency to once a month or less. Always adjust based on the specific climate conditions and soil drainage where the plant is located."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Colubrina greggii thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day to promote healthy growth and vibrant foliage. In extremely hot and arid climates, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch and stress. Ensure the planting site receives adequate sunlight, but also consider the local climate to provide the right balance. If the plant receives too much shade, it may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. Adjust the planting location if needed based on observed growth patterns."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Colubrina greggii helps maintain its shape and encourages healthy growth. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged branches first to maintain plant health. Trim back overgrown or crossing branches to improve air circulation within the plant. If necessary, you can perform a more significant cut back to shape the plant, but avoid pruning more than one-third of the plant at one time. Regular light pruning helps maintain a tidy appearance and encourages bushier growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sierra nakedwood","description":"Colubrina greggii is a species of flowering plant in the buckthorn family, Rhamnaceae, that is commonly known as the Sierra nakedwood or Gregg's colubrina. It is native to eastern Mexico, with a disjunct population in southern Texas in the United States. It is very similar to C. arborescens of Southern Florida and the Caribbean, and herbarium specimens of the two species are difficult to distinguish. The name honours American botanist Josiah Gregg (1806 – 1850), who...","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States"],"other_name":["Sierra nakedwood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Colubrina greggii"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17713,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Mammillaria geminispina requires careful watering to avoid root rot. Water the plant thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, which is spring through summer, you may water every two to three weeks depending on humidity and temperature. In the fall and winter months, the plant enters a rest period and needs less frequent watering, sometimes as sparingly as once a month. Always check the top inch of the soil for dryness before watering. Additionally, use well-draining soil to prevent water from accumulating in the pot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mammillaria geminispina thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It does best when placed in a location that receives plenty of light, such as a south- or east-facing window. Direct sunlight can be too intense and lead to sunburn, so it's important to provide some form of filtered light if the plant will be in direct sun. If growing outdoors, choose a spot with partial shade to protect it from the harsh afternoon sun. During the winter months, you may need to supplement with artificial grow lights if natural light is insufficient."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Mammillaria geminispina is minimal and generally only necessary to remove dead or damaged parts of the plant. Use clean, sterilized tools to avoid introducing disease. Occasionally, this cactus may produce pups or offsets, which can be removed to propagate new plants or to maintain its current size and shape. If removing pups, ensure they are fully developed and minimize damage to the main plant. Regular inspection will help you identify any parts that may need to be trimmed to keep the cactus healthy and aesthetically pleasing."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Mammillaria geminispina (twin spined cactus) is a species of flowering plant in the family Cactaceae, native to central Mexico. It grows to 25 cm (10 in) tall by 50 cm (20 in) broad. The clustering spherical stems, 8 cm in diameter, are covered in white down and white spines. Carmine pink flowers are borne in summer and autumn.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Spider mites"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Mammillaria geminispina"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17119,"attracts":["Insects"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia foliosa, commonly known as a bladderwort, is a carnivorous aquatic plant that requires a specific water environment to thrive. Ideally, it should be grown in soft, acidic to neutral water without lime content. The water should be poor in nutrients to mimic its natural habitat, as it acquires nutrients primarily from trapping small aquatic prey. Regularly changing the water to prevent stagnation and algae bloom is crucial. Rainwater, distilled water, or RO (reverse osmosis) water is preferable. Ensure the water level is consistent, submerging the plant while providing the necessary support for its floating habit."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia foliosa thrives in bright but indirect sunlight typical of a tropical aquatic environment. It requires several hours of good light daily but must be protected from intense, direct sunlight that can cause the water to heat excessively or promote excessive algae growth. Ideally, place it where it gets gentle morning sun or filtered light throughout the day if grown in a container. When cultivated outdoors, positioning it under a tree canopy or in a part-sun location in a pond setting can help provide the needed light conditions without overheating or drying out too rapidly."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Utricularia foliosa involves removing any dead or decaying plant matter to maintain its health and encourage growth. Since it is an aquatic plant, pruning is generally minimal and focuses on maintaining its shape and freeing it from overcrowding. If the plant becomes too dense or starts blooming poorly, gently remove older, less productive sections, usually visible by their darker, sometimes mushy appearance. Use clean, sharp scissors to prevent introducing pathogens during this process. Regularly inspect and remove any trapped large debris or dead prey that might accumulate in the bladder traps to keep the plant in optimal health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Leafy Bladderwort","description":"Utricularia foliosa, the leafy bladderwort, is a large suspended aquatic carnivorous plant that belongs to the genus Utricularia (family Lentibulariaceae). It is probably a perennial plant. U. foliosa is native to Africa and North and South America, widely distributed among many countries.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Leafy Bladderwort"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Utricularia foliosa"],"soil":["Wet","Marshy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Ensure it is not subjected to sudden changes in light conditions, as this can shock the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Dyschoriste linearis is not highly demanding but can promote healthier growth and maintain a desired shape. Water the plant during extended dry spells but avoid overwatering, as it does not thrive in waterlogged conditions. It's essential to allow the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to prevent root rot. During the active growing season in spring and early summer, ensure the soil remains consistently moist, but reduce the frequency of watering in the fall and winter when the plant's growth slows down."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Briza media thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideal conditions would mimic its natural meadow habitats with plenty of light and some shelter from intense afternoon sun."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Briza media involves cutting back dead and damaged foliage to promote healthy growth and to maintain an attractive appearance. This is generally done in early spring before new growth begins. You can also trim back the whole plant by about one-third after it has ceased flowering to encourage a fresh flush of growth and to prevent it from self-seeding aggressively. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17613,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Medicago marina, commonly known as coastal medick or sea medick, thrives best in well-drained soil and does not require excessive watering. It is a drought-tolerant plant adapted to Mediterranean climates with dry summers. Watering should be infrequent, only when the soil is completely dry to the touch, to mimic its native arid conditions. Over-watering can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases, thus it’s important to let the soil dry out between waterings. Reduce watering during its dormant winter period. Monitoring the soil moisture levels helps in avoiding unnecessary water stress or overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Medicago marina prefers full sun exposure to thrive. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day, which is ideal for optimal flowering and healthy growth. Originating from coastal regions, it is accustomed to bright environments. If grown in partial shade, it may result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. Ensure it is positioned in the garden where it receives ample sunlight, preferably a south-facing spot if grown in the northern hemisphere. Protect it from intense afternoon sun in extremely hot climates to prevent scorching, especially during peak summer."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Medicago marina involves removing dead or diseased stems and foliage to promote healthier growth. It should be done in early spring or late fall when the plant is less active. Regular pruning helps maintain its shape, encourages denser foliage, and prevents the plant from becoming too woody. Use sharp, sterile tools to make clean cuts at a node or just above a leaf. This helps in preventing diseases and encourages faster recovery. Since it can spread out, some light pruning to control its spread might be necessary depending on the garden setup and personal preference."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Coastal medick","description":"Medicago marina is a plant species of the genus Medicago. It is native to the Mediterranean basin but is found worldwide. It forms a symbiotic relationship with the bacterium Sinorhizobium meliloti, which is capable of nitrogen fixation. Avoid direct, harsh sunlight as it can lead to undesirable microalgae growth and temperature fluctuations in the tank."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Okenia hypogaea does not require pruning, as it is a marine animal rather than a plant species. Once established, it is relatively drought-tolerant and requires watering only during extended dry periods. Ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch and to ensure the plant does not become overly stressed. When planted in too much shade, the flowering may be reduced, and the growth can become leggy. Adjust the planting location to balance sunlight and ensure healthy development and blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Physocarpus malvaceus should be done in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. This plant benefits from thinning cuts to improve air circulation and remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches. Regular pruning will help maintain its shape and encourage vigorous growth. To enhance blooming, cut back the oldest stems to ground level, as the plant flowers on new wood. Rejuvenation pruning, where the entire plant is cut back aggressively, may be done every few years to refresh its appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"mallow-leaf ninebark","description":"Physocarpus malvaceus is a species of flowering plant in the rose family known by the common name mallow ninebark. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17418,"attracts":["Bees","Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Epidendrum fimbriatum, like many orchids, requires careful watering to thrive. Water the plant thoroughly once a week, allowing the water to drain completely to prevent root rot. It's crucial to let the potting medium dry out slightly between waterings, as the roots should not remain constantly wet. In warmer months or dryer environments, you might need to water more frequently. Ensure you're using distilled or rainwater to avoid mineral build-up, and periodically mist the leaves to maintain humidity, as Epidendrums prefer a moist atmosphere."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Epidendrum fimbriatum thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can handle some direct sunlight, especially morning sun, but it's best to avoid the harsh midday rays which can scorch the leaves. Indoors, place the plant near an east or west-facing window where it can receive ample light throughout the day without being in the path of direct sunlight. You can supplement with artificial grow lights if natural lighting conditions are insufficient. Adequate lighting is essential for this orchid to bloom and stay healthy."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Epidendrum fimbriatum should focus on removing spent flower spikes and dead or damaged leaves to encourage healthy growth. Once the flowers have faded and the spike has turned brown, cut it back to the base with sterilized scissors to prevent disease spread. Regularly inspect and trim away any yellowing or unhealthy foliage. This helps improve air circulation around the plant and redirects its energy to developing new, healthy blooms and foliage, fostering a more vibrant growing environment for the orchid."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Fringed Epidendrum","description":"Epidendrum fimbriatum is a terrestrial (sometimes epiphytic) orchid native to high altitudes (2.2—3.4 km) in Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Venezuela.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Fringed Epidendrum"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mealybugs","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["December"],"scientific_name":["Epidendrum fimbriatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Orchid mix"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adequate drainage is crucial to prevent waterlogging but maintaining a swampy or consistently damp condition is ideal. If grown indoors, using a saucer filled with water can help maintain humidity and moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium palustre prefers full sun to partial shade conditions. It naturally thrives in areas that receive ample sunlight during the day, but can also tolerate light shade. The plant should receive at least 4-6 hours of sunlight daily to ensure robust growth and flowering. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade is beneficial to prevent the plant from experiencing excess heat and potential drought stress, although its preference for moist environments often mitigates this risk. Pruning can be done throughout the growing season to maintain shape and prevent it from overtaking other plants. Deadheading flowers will also encourage a more prolonged blooming period and prevent unwanted self-seeding."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Common Marsh-bedstraw","description":"Galium palustre, the common marsh bedstraw or simply marsh-bedstraw, is a herbaceous annual plant of the family Rubiaceae. If grown in too much shade, the plant may exhibit slower growth and reduced flowering. Ensure the location chosen provides a balance suitable for the climate and specific conditions of your garden."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Magnolia macrophylla should be done minimally, primarily to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring, just before new growth starts. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts at the branch collar. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the tree and reduce flower production. If necessary, thinning cuts can be made to allow light into the canopy and improve air circulation. Regular inspection helps identify if any targeted pruning is needed to support the plant's structure and health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bigleaf magnolia","description":"Magnolia macrophylla, the bigleaf magnolia, is a deciduous magnolia native to the southeastern United States and eastern Mexico. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17812,"attracts":["Hummingbirds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Fouquieria macdougalii, commonly known as Ocotillo, prefers minimal watering, especially in its early stages. During the growing season, water it once every two weeks, ensuring that the soil is completely dry in between watering sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to allow the soil to dry out. In winter, reduce watering as the plant goes dormant and requires significantly less moisture. If you notice the leaves turning yellow or dropping, it's a sign that you might be over-watering. Always ensure proper drainage to prevent stagnant water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Fouquieria macdougalii thrives in full sun, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to perform well. It is adapted to deserts and arid regions, so it handles intense sunlight beautifully. The more sunlight it receives, the better its blooming and overall health will be. If growing indoors or in less sunny areas, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive maximum sunlight. However, ensure that it does not get overshadowed by other objects. Lack of ample sunlight can result in leggy growth and fewer flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Fouquieria macdougalii should be done sparingly and mainly to maintain shape or remove dead or damaged branches. The best time for pruning is in the early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning tools to cut the stems back to their base or to the main branch they originate from. Avoid cutting the top tips of healthy stems, as this is where the plant will produce flowers. Minimal pruning is often best since this plant naturally grows in an attractive, sculptural form. Avoid heavy pruning, which can damage the plant's growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican tree ocotillo","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","United States (Arizona)"],"other_name":["Mexican tree ocotillo"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Fouquieria macdougalii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17517,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Opuntia lasiacantha, like many cacti, requires minimal watering. This plant is drought-tolerant and should be watered sparingly. During the growing season (spring and summer), water the plant thoroughly whenever the soil is completely dry, roughly every two to three weeks, depending on the humidity and temperature. In the fall and winter months, reduce watering to once a month or less. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the plant is in well-draining soil and that any excess water is able to drain away quickly. Always err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Opuntia lasiacantha thrives in full sunlight. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure robust growth and flowering. If placed indoors, the plant should be situated in a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. If outdoor cultivation is preferred, choose a location that is sunny and dry. Be aware that sudden exposure to intense sunlight when moving the plant outdoors can cause sunburn. Gradually acclimate it to increased light intensity over a few weeks in the spring to prevent damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Opuntia lasiacantha is generally minimal, focusing on the removal of damaged or diseased pads to maintain the plant's health and appearance. Use a pair of sharp, sterile pruning shears to cut off any pads that appear shriveled, rotting, or infested with pests. If the plant becomes overly large or unruly, you can also selectively remove pads to shape the plant, ensuring adequate airflow between sections to prevent disease. Always wear gloves and protective clothing when handling this cactus to avoid injury from its sharp spines."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Opuntia lasiacantha"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16226,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Colubrina texensis, commonly known as Texas Snakewood, is a drought-tolerant plant, well adapted to arid conditions. It requires minimal watering; ensuring the soil is allowed to dry out completely between waterings is crucial. Overwatering can harm the plant, leading to root rot. During the growing season (spring and summer), you can water it once every two weeks if there has been no rainfall. In the dormant season (fall and winter), reduce watering to once a month or less. Always check the soil moisture before watering to avoid excess soil moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Texas Snakewood thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. It is well-suited for hot, arid climates and can tolerate extreme heat, making it ideal for xeriscaping and dry gardens. When grown in shaded areas, its growth may become leggy, and it may produce fewer flowers and fruits. Ideally, plant it in an area where it can soak up abundant sunshine throughout the day. However, once established, it can adapt to partial shade but will not perform at its best compared to full sun exposure."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Colubrina texensis is not typically required for health reasons but can be performed to maintain shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time for pruning is during late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp tools to make precise cuts. Remove any crossing branches or those that detract from the natural shape of the plant. It's also beneficial to thin out dense areas to improve air circulation. Regularly inspect the plant for pests or disease and remove affected parts promptly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Texas Snakewood","description":"Colubrina texensis, the Texas snakewood or Texas hog plum, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rhamnaceae, native to Texas and northeastern Mexico. A 3 to 6 ft (0.9 to 1.8 m) deciduous shrub with zig-zagging branches and patterned bark, it is typically found growing in dry, poor soils.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Texas Snakewood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Colubrina texensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17020,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Sphaeralcea fendleri, commonly known as Fendler's Globemallow, is a drought-tolerant plant that requires minimal watering. In its native habitat, it thrives in dry, arid conditions and is therefore well-suited to xeriscape gardens. Water it sparingly, allowing the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. Over-watering can lead to root rot and other plant health issues. During the summer growing season, you may water more frequently if the leaves start to wilt, but always err on the side of less water rather than more."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Sphaeralcea fendleri thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish. This ensures healthy growth and abundant flowering. In less sunny conditions, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer blooms. While it can tolerate partial shade, particularly in hot climates, optimal flowering occurs with full sun exposure. If growing indoors or in a garden setting, choose a location where the plant will receive ample direct sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sphaeralcea fendleri is not typically necessary, but occasional trimming can promote a bushier growth and remove any dead or damaged stems. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring, just before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut back the stems to a desirable shape and height. Avoid over-pruning, as this can stress the plant. Removing spent blooms during the flowering season can also encourage more blooms to appear."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Fendler's Globemallow","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["Fendler's Globemallow"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Sphaeralcea fendleri"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16920,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Richardia brasiliensis, commonly known as Brazil Pusley, thrives best in well-drained soil and requires moderate watering. Ensure that the soil is kept consistently moist, but be cautious not to overwater, as soggy conditions can lead to root rot. During dry spells or if grown in containers, watering once a week should suffice, increasing frequency during extreme heat. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to maintain a balance that prevents overwatering while ensuring the plant receives enough moisture to stay healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Richardia brasiliensis prefers full sun to partial shade environments for optimal growth. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily, which promotes better flowering and overall plant vigor. In regions with intense afternoon sunlight, providing some light shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. If grown indoors or in a shadier spot, expect reduced flowering. Therefore, choose a location that allows ample sunshine access while protecting it from the harshest midday rays in particularly hot climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Richardia brasiliensis is not a rigorous task, but it can help maintain the plant's appearance and prevent it from becoming invasive. Trim back the branches and stems lightly during the growing season if they start to look leggy or if you want to control its spread. Remove any dead or damaged leaves and stems to encourage new growth. This plant can spread aggressively, so regular trimming can also prevent unwanted growth into other areas of your garden. A good cleanup in early spring can prepare the plant for a healthy growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Tropical Mexican Clover","description":"Richardia brasiliensis is a species of flowering plant in the coffee family known by the English common names tropical Mexican clover, Brazilian calla-lily, white-eye, and Brazil pusley. In Brazil it is known as poaia branca. It is native to South America. It is an introduced species and sometimes an invasive weed in many other places, including Hawaii, Indonesia, Japan, and Thailand. It is a weed of citrus groves in Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Brazil"],"other_name":["Tropical Mexican Clover"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Richardia brasiliensis"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
