{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17318,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ferocactus pilosus, like most cacti, requires moderate watering. During its growing season, which typically spans the warmer months, water the cactus thoroughly but allow the soil to dry out completely between watering sessions. It's crucial to avoid overwatering, as this can lead to root rot. In the winter, reduce watering significantly since the cactus is dormant and its water requirements decrease. Water only when the soil is dry to the touch, generally every 4 to 6 weeks during the colder months, depending on the humidity levels in your home or environment."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ferocactus pilosus thrives best when exposed to full sunlight. Ideally, position the cactus in a location that receives at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. If the cactus is kept indoors, a south or west-facing window is perfect for providing adequate light. Inadequate sunlight can cause elongated or weak growth, so supplemental lighting might be necessary if natural sunlight is insufficient. However, monitor for sunburn, especially if transitioning from a lower light environment to direct sun, by gradually increasing light exposure to help it acclimate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ferocactus pilosus is generally minimal and typically only involves the removal of old, dead, or diseased parts. It’s important to handle any pruning tasks carefully, using sterilized tools to prevent infection. Remove unhealthy or damaged sections as they appear, cutting close to the stem to avoid stubs where pests or diseases can enter. Also, occasionally inspect the base for offsets or pups, which can be removed and potted independently. This species does not require shaping or regular cutting, but maintaining its health through gentle pruning can encourage a robust growth pattern."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":"Ferocactus pilosus, also known as Mexican lime cactus (Viznaga De Lima) or Mexican fire barrel, is a species of cactus in North America.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Ferocactus pilosus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16324,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ecballium elaterium, commonly known as the squirting cucumber, thrives in dry, rocky, and well-drained soils. It is drought-tolerant and requires minimal watering. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so it's crucial to water sparingly. Allow the soil to completely dry out between waterings. During periods of prolonged dry conditions, occasional deep watering can help sustain the plant, but in general, minimal attention is needed. During its dormant season in winter, reduce watering significantly. This plant naturally grows in arid environments and is well adapted to conserving water effectively."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ecballium elaterium prefers full sunlight to partial shade, although it thrives best in full sun locations. Ensure it receives at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to encourage optimal growth and flowering. In regions with extremely hot temperatures, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to prevent the plant from experiencing stress or sunburn. However, too much shade will lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms. Plant it in an open area where it isn’t overshadowed by larger plants or structures, simulating the sunny, exposed conditions of its native habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ecballium elaterium isn't typically necessary for its health but can be done for aesthetic reasons or to control its spread in a garden space. If pruning is desired, it’s best to do so in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthier growth. Since it is a trailing plant, some gardeners may prune to prevent it from taking over other plants. Use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and avoid reducing the plant too drastically in one go, as it can be counterproductive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"squirting cucumber","description":"Ecballium is a genus of flowering plants in the family Cucurbitaceae containing a single species, Ecballium elaterium, also called the squirting cucumber or exploding cucumber (but not to be confused with Cyclanthera explodens). It gets its unusual name from the fact that, when ripe, it squirts a stream of mucilaginous liquid containing its seeds, which can be seen with the naked eye. It is thus considered to have rapid plant movement.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mediterranean","Western Asia"],"other_name":["squirting cucumber"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ecballium elaterium"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17120,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Utricularia inflata is an aquatic plant which should be grown in water that mimics its natural habitat, such as ponds or slow-moving streams. The water should be rich in organic matter and soft to slightly acidic as it allows for optimal growth conditions for this carnivorous species. Regularly topping up water levels as they evaporate will ensure the plant remains healthy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Utricularia inflata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It should ideally be placed in a location where it can receive ample morning light but be shielded from the harsh direct afternoon sun, which can be too intense. If grown indoors, a spot near a window with filtered light is ideal. Outdoors, partial shade can help protect the plant from too much direct sun while allowing it to photosynthesize effectively. Ensuring it receives around 4-6 hours of indirect sunlight will promote healthy, continuous growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Utricularia inflata involves removing dead or decaying plant material to keep the water environment clean and prevent the growth of algae or mold. Since this is a true aquatic plant, pruning is minimal and generally consists of gently removing any dead leaves or stems using tweezers or scissors. This encourages healthier growth by redirecting energy to new growth. Most of its maintenance is about ensuring the environment is free of excess buildup of organic matter and maintaining water quality."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"swollen bladderwort","description":"Utricularia inflata, commonly known as the swollen bladderwort, inflated bladderwort, or large floating bladderwort, is a large suspended aquatic carnivorous plant that belongs to the genus Utricularia. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17912,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Neopringlea integrifolia requires regular watering to maintain moderately moist soil, especially during its growing season. Ensure the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, as excessive moisture can lead to root rot. During warmer months, water the plant more frequently, checking that the top inch of the soil feels dry before watering again. However, reduce watering during the plant's dormant period in the cooler months, allowing the soil to dry out somewhat between waterings. Always avoid standing water at the base of the plant, as it prefers consistency but not excessive wetness."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Neopringlea integrifolia thrives in environments with full sun exposure. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to ensure optimal growth and flowering. When grown indoors, place the plant near a south-facing window where it can receive ample sunlight throughout the day. If natural sunlight is insufficient, consider using grow lights to supplement the light exposure. Insufficient light can lead to poor growth and lack of blooms, so it is important to monitor the light conditions and adjust as necessary. Avoid too much shade, as it can cause the plant to become leggy and weak."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Neopringlea integrifolia involves removing dead, damaged, or diseased branches to maintain plant health and encourage new growth. Perform pruning in the early spring before the growing season commences. Also, trim back any overgrown areas to maintain the desired shape and size of the plant. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and prevent disease transmission. Regular pruning helps improve air circulation within the plant, reduces the risk of pest infestations, and enhances the overall aesthetics of the plant. Avoid heavy pruning as it may stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":null,"description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico"],"other_name":null,"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Neopringlea integrifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16134,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cardiospermum corindum, commonly known as the balloon vine, prefers moderate watering. Ensure the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged; excessive water can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, increase the frequency of watering to support healthy growth. Reduce watering in the fall and winter months, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. Always use well-draining soil and pots with drainage holes to prevent water from accumulating."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cardiospermum corindum thrives in full sun to partial shade. It requires at least six hours of direct sunlight daily to flourish, which helps the plant produce energy for growth and flowering. In hotter climates, provide some afternoon shade to protect it from intense heat, which can scorch the leaves. If grown indoors, place it in a location that receives ample bright, indirect light or near a south-facing window. Insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cardiospermum corindum should focus on maintaining a tidy appearance and encouraging bushier growth. Prune the plant in early spring before the new growth starts, removing any dead or damaged stems. Trim back any overly long vines to promote branching and more compact growth. It's also helpful to pinch back the growing tips periodically during the growing season to encourage fuller foliage. Regular pruning will help manage its growth and prevent it from becoming too sprawling."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Faux Persil","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Tropical regions"],"other_name":["Faux Persil"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Cardiospermum corindum"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16100,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Bromus kalmii, commonly known as Kalm's brome, is a grass species that thrives well in moist to dry soil conditions. It's important not to overwater this plant, as it is adapted to a variety of moisture levels and can suffer from root rot if left in standing water. During periods of active growth in spring and early summer, water the plant moderately, ensuring the soil remains slightly moist but not soggy. In drier spells or periods of dormancy, reduce watering, allowing the topsoil to dry out slightly between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bromus kalmii prefers full sun to partial shade conditions for optimal growth. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, growth might be less vigorous, and the plant could become leggy if sunlight is insufficient. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can be beneficial to protect the plant from intense heat. Ensuring adequate sunlight will promote robust growth and healthy foliage, giving Kalm's brome its best chance to thrive."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Bromus kalmii is minimal, primarily involving the removal of spent flower heads and old foliage to maintain appearance and promote healthy growth. After the flowering season, you can cut the flower stalks down to the base to prevent unwanted self-seeding and encourage a tidy look. Additionally, in late winter or early spring, cut back old, brown foliage to make way for new growth. Regular trimming of old growth also helps in minimizing pest infestations and disease prevalence in the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Prairie Brome","description":"Bromus kalmii, Arctic brome and Prairie brome, is a species of brome grass. It is a native bunchgrass in the North-central and Northeastern United States, the Great Lakes region, and eastern Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Prairie Brome"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Bromus kalmii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17419,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hymenocallis occidentalis, commonly known as the spider lily, prefers consistent moisture, especially during its growing and blooming seasons. The soil should be kept slightly moist at all times, but be very careful not to overwater, as this plant does not appreciate soggy conditions and its bulbs can rot. During its dormant period in the winter, reduce watering significantly and allow the soil to dry out between waterings. To maintain optimal moisture levels, consider using a well-draining potting mix if growing it in a container or ensure excellent drainage in garden beds."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The spider lily thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, provide them with at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day for optimal growth and blooming. In particularly hot regions, some afternoon shade can help prevent the leaves from scorching. If grown indoors, place the plant near a bright south-facing window to ensure it receives sufficient light. However, ensure that the plant is not exposed to intense midday sun, which can cause leaf burn. Adjust light levels accordingly to find a balance that promotes robust growth without damage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hymenocallis occidentalis is relatively minimal. Remove spent flowers as soon as they start to fade to encourage further blooming and prevent the plant from spending energy on seed production. Yellow or dead leaves can also be trimmed back at their base to keep the plant tidy, but avoid excessive pruning as the leaves are essential for photosynthesis. Perform any necessary pruning during the plant’s active growing season, and avoid disturbing it during its dormancy in the winter months to prevent unnecessary stress or damage."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"woodland spider-lily","description":"Hymenocallis occidentalis is a plant species native to the southern United States. It is known along the Gulf Coast from South Carolina to Texas, and in the Mississippi Valley as far north as southern Illinois and Indiana. It is also cultivated as an ornamental elsewhere because of its showy, sweet-smelling flowers. Common names include woodland spider-lily, hammock spider-lily or northern spider-lily.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["woodland spider-lily"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Bulb"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Hymenocallis occidentalis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16423,"attracts":["Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Galium virgatum, commonly known as bedstraw, prefers consistently moist soil but not waterlogged. It's best to water this plant regularly, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between watering sessions. During dry spells, particularly hot summers, increase the watering frequency to maintain soil moisture levels. However, ensure proper drainage to avoid root rot, as the plant does not tolerate standing water. Adjust watering according to the plant's location; it may need more frequent watering if grown in sunny or windy spots where soil dries out more rapidly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Galium virgatum thrives in partial to full sun positions, which allows it to perform at its best. It can tolerate a range of light conditions, from full shade to full sun, but balanced exposure is ideal. In regions with very hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent potential leaf scorch. The plant is versatile and can adapt to various lighting environments as long as the soil moisture is adequately managed. Understanding the specific microclimate and adjusting the light exposure accordingly will promote healthy growth and abundant flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Galium virgatum is generally straightforward and involves removing dead or yellowing stems to encourage healthy growth. This can be done in early spring or after flowering to maintain a tidy appearance and control its spread, as it can become quite sprawling. Light trimming can be done throughout the growing season if necessary. Deadheading spent flowers can promote further blooming. Always use clean and sharp pruning shears to avoid damaging the plant. Removing any invasive growths that may develop is also recommended to prevent it from overtaking other plants nearby."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Southwestern bedstraw","description":"Galium virgatum, common name southwestern bedstraw, is a North American species of plants in the Rubiaceae. It is native to the south-central part of the United States, primarily in the southern Great Plains from Texas to Missouri, but with scattered populations as far east as South Carolina.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["Southwestern bedstraw"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Galium virgatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}
